factoid: The staff officer was standing in front.
The staff officer pointed out something to the general.
The general looked through his field glass.
The general said that the enemy would be fired on at the crossing.
The general asked why the enemy were dawdling there.
The enemy could be seen by the naked eye on the opposite side.
A milk‑white cloud arose from the enemy's battery.
A distant report of a shot was heard.
Our troops were seen hurrying to the crossing.
Nesvítski rose.
Nesvítski went up to the general.
Nesvítski was smiling.
Nesvítski asked the general if he would like a little refreshment.
The general said that it was a bad business.
The general said that our men had been wasting time.
Nesvítski asked if he should ride over to the general.
The general said yes to Nesvítski.
The general repeated the order to tell the hussars to cross last.
The general repeated the order to tell the hussars to fire the bridge as he ordered.
The general repeated the order that the inflammable material on the bridge must be reinspected.
Nesvítski said very good.
Nesvítski called the Cossack with his horse.
Nesvítski told the Cossack to put away the knapsack and flask.
Nesvítski rode off by the winding path down the hill.
The general said to the artillery officer that they should see how far it would carry, Captain.
The general told the artillery officer to have a little fun to pass the time.
The artillery officer commanded the crew to their guns.
The men came running gaily from their campfires.
The men began loading.
The command "One!" was given.
Number one jumped aside.
The gun rang out with a deafening metallic roar.
A whistling grenade flew above the heads of our troops below the hill.
The grenade fell far short of the enemy.
A little smoke showed the spot where the grenade burst.
The faces of officers and men brightened at the sound.
Everyone got up and began watching the movements of our troops below.
The movements of our troops below were plainly visible as if a stone’s throw away.
The movements of the approaching enemy were farther off.
The sun came fully out from behind the clouds.
The clear sound of the solitary shot merged with the brilliance of the bright sunshine in a joyous impression.
Two of the enemy’s shots had already flown across the bridge.
There was a crush across the bridge.
Prince Nesvítski stood halfway across the bridge.
Prince Nesvítski had alighted from his horse.
Prince Nesvítski's big body was jammed against the railings.
Prince Nesvítski looked back laughing to the Cossack.
The Cossack stood a few steps behind Prince Nesvítski.
The Cossack was holding two horses by their bridles.
Each time Prince Nesvítski tried to move on, soldiers and carts pushed him back.
Soldiers and carts pressed Prince Nesvítski against the railings.
Prince Nesvítski could only smile.
The Cossack said to a convoy soldier with a wagon that he was a fine fellow.
The convoy soldier with a wagon was pressing onto the infantrymen.
The infantrymen were crowded together close to the convoy soldier's wheels and horses.
The Cossack said that the convoy soldier could not wait a moment.
The Cossack said that the convoy soldier did not see that the general wanted to pass.
The general lowered his field glass.
The general shrugged his shoulders.
